name: King Solomon
shortDescription: The wisest king of Israel, builder of the First Temple, author of Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, and Song of Songs - paradigm of divine wisdom
longDescription: King Solomon (Hebrew: Shlomo, from shalom meaning 'peace') was the son of King David and Bathsheba, and the third king of Israel's united monarchy. His reign (c. 970-931 BCE) marked the golden age of Israel's power, wealth, and wisdom. When God appeared to the young Solomon in a dream at Gibeon and offered him anything he desired, Solomon asked not for long life, wealth, or victory over enemies, but for 'an understanding heart to judge Your people, to discern between good and evil' (1 Kings 3:9). Pleased with this humble request, God granted Solomon wisdom surpassing all who came before or after, plus the wealth and honor he had not requested. This 'wisdom of Solomon' became proverbial: he composed 3,000 proverbs and 1,005 songs, spoke of trees, beasts, birds, fish, and received visitors like the Queen of Sheba who came to test his renowned wisdom. Solomon built the magnificent First Temple in Jerusalem, fulfilling his father David's dream, and established Israel as a commercial and diplomatic power. Yet his later years saw tragic compromise: his many foreign wives turned his heart toward their gods, and his heavy taxation and forced labor sowed seeds of the kingdom's eventual division. In Jewish tradition, Solomon authored three biblical books: Proverbs (wisdom for the young), Ecclesiastes (reflection in old age), and Song of Songs (love's passion in youth). The apocryphal Wisdom of Solomon and legends of the Seal of Solomon commanding demons expanded his mystical reputation. For the Epistle of James, Solomon represents the paradigm of one who asked God for wisdom and received generously (James 1:5) - 'the wisdom from above' that James urges all believers to seek.

biography.parentage: Son of King David and Bathsheba
biography.earlyLife: Born after the death of David and Bathsheba's first child; given the name Jedidiah ('beloved of YHWH') by Nathan the prophet. Chosen by David as successor despite older brothers.
biography.calling: Anointed king by Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet at Gihon spring (1 Kings 1)

majorEvents.description: God appeared in a dream offering anything; Solomon asked for 'an understanding heart' and received wisdom, wealth, and honor
Solomon's wisdom demonstrated by threatening to divide a baby - revealing the true mother. 'All Israel... saw that the wisdom of God was in him.'
Seven years constructing the magnificent Temple; dedicated with the Ark of the Covenant and God's glory filling the sanctuary

majorEvents.event: Visit of the Queen of Sheba
majorEvents.description: The Queen came to test Solomon's wisdom with hard questions; she declared 'the half was not told me' and gave lavish gifts
Composed 3,000 proverbs and 1,005 songs; traditionally authored Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, and Song of Songs
Solomon's foreign wives turned his heart after other gods; God pronounced the kingdom would be torn from his son

achievements: Wisest man who ever lived - wisdom surpassing all the East and Egypt
Built the First Temple in Jerusalem
Established Israel as a major commercial and diplomatic power
Authored Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Song of Songs (traditional attribution)
Received the Queen of Sheba and kings of the earth
failures: Married 700 wives and 300 concubines, many foreign
Foreign wives turned his heart after other gods
Built high places for Chemosh, Molech, and other deities
Heavy taxation and forced labor burdened Israel
Sowed seeds for the kingdom's division after his death
biography.death: Died in Jerusalem after reigning 40 years; buried in the City of David. Kingdom divided under his son Rehoboam.
biography.legacy: Paradigm of wisdom sought from God; builder of God's Temple; yet also a warning that wisdom without faithfulness leads to ruin

askingForWisdom.quote: 'Give your servant an understanding heart to judge your people, that I may discern between good and evil.' It pleased the Lord that Solomon had asked this.
askingForWisdom.jamesConnection: James 1:5 echoes this: 'If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask God, who gives generously to all without reproach, and it will be given him.'

wisdomExtent.description: God gave Solomon wisdom and understanding 'as vast as the sand on the seashore.' His wisdom exceeded all the people of the East and all the wisdom of Egypt. He spoke of trees from the cedar to the hyssop, and of animals, birds, reptiles, and fish. People came from all nations to hear his wisdom.

templeBuilding.significance: Fulfilled David's dream to build a house for YHWH; central sanctuary for Israel's worship

dedication.description: Solomon gathered all Israel; the Ark was brought in; the glory cloud of YHWH filled the Temple so the priests could not minister

solomonsPrayer.theme: Solomon's dedication prayer - a model of intercession asking God to hear prayers made toward this place

askingWisdom.solomonExample: Solomon asked God for wisdom rather than wealth or power (1 Kings 3)
askingWisdom.jamesTeaching: James 1:5 - 'If any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask God, who gives generously to all without reproach'
askingWisdom.connection: Solomon is the paradigm for James's instruction - the one who asked and received 'wisdom from above'

wisdomFromAbove.proverbsTeaching: Proverbs (Solomon's book) describes wisdom as pure, peaceable, from God
wisdomFromAbove.jamesTeaching: James 3:17 - 'But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle...'
wisdomFromAbove.connection: James's description of heavenly wisdom echoes Solomon's teachings in Proverbs

warningAboutWealth.solomonFall: Solomon's wealth and foreign alliances led to compromise and idolatry
warningAboutWealth.jamesTeaching: James 1:9-11, 5:1-6 warns about the dangers of wealth and trusting in riches
warningAboutWealth.connection: Solomon's tragic end warns of dangers James addresses regarding rich and poor
